messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Iron Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hey NC; Well I for one would be one of the first investors in your patina paste. The moist, wet, purple, feel and look on iron tsuba is a most desirable
messages.messageBody:
Hey NC;

Well I for one would be one of the first investors in your patina paste.

The moist, wet, purple, feel and look on iron tsuba is a most desirable feature for collectors.

This condition I have only found on early iron tsuba forged from sand iron. The silky feel and texture of the iron I am quite certain is due to the quality of the iron plate and the method of forging.

The color I am not certain of.

Not all early tsuba even of good quality plate develop this purple color. Some tend to go towards black and some towards brown.

I know a tsuba collector who claims he can create this patina but the tsuba I have seen from him have fallen far short of the mark in my humble opinion.

Interesting question.

John

----- Original Message -----
From: nihontochicken
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, June 19, 2003 8:24 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Iron Tsuba?


Lou and Folk -

Let me piggyback here. The "neatest" iron tsuba I have seen
have "wet, sticky, purplish black" patina. I doubt this is due only
to the properties of the base metal, but rather depend greatly on the
care and maintenance of the tsuba. What is it that promotes this
type of patina? Just so I can market the "Chicken Brand Sticky
Purple Patina Paste". ;o)

NC

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, JapaneseSwords@a... wrote:
> Can someone explain why many good iron tsuba are said to have a
purplish
> patina? Is this just a characteristic of good early Owari tsuba or
does this
> cross over into other schools? Any photos would be a great
learning tool too.
> Thanks in advance.
>
> Lou
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Iron Tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Can someone explain why many good iron tsuba are said to have a purplish patina?  Is this just a characteristic of good early Owari tsuba or does this cross
messages.messageBody:
Can someone explain why many good iron tsuba are said to have a purplish
patina? Is this just a characteristic of good early Owari tsuba or does this
cross over into other schools? Any photos would be a great learning tool too.
Thanks in advance.

Lou


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
